discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The Network Visualizer provides a diagram of the implemented topology of all VCNs in a selected region and tenancy. 
https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Network/Concepts/network_visualizer.htm

questions.question_text: Which tool provides a diagram of the implemented topology of all Virtual Cloud Networks (VCNs) in a selected region and tenancy?

discussion.content:
Correct Answer: D
Customer Premises Equipment (CPE). The explanation is that CPE is an object in OCI that represents your on-premises router or VPN device that connects to your VCN via a site-to-site VPN. A site-to-site VPN is a secure and encrypted connection between your on-premises network and your VCN over the public internet. To set up a site-to-site VPN, you need to create a CPE object with your router's public IP address and other information, such as vendor and platform. You also need to create a Dynamic Routing Gateway (DRG) object in your VCN and attach it to your VCN. Then, you need to create an IPSec connection between your CPE and DRG, which will create two redundant VPN tunnels for high availability.

questions.question_text:
Your DevOps team needs to interconnect the on-premises network to the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) resources, such as a managed database that resides in a private subnet. They indicate that they have a low budget and their bandwidth requirements are minimal, so you decide that a site-to-site VPN is the best option. They provide you with their router public IP address. You need to create an object in OCI that represents this router.
Which object would you create?
Which TWO are key benefits of setting up Site-to-Site VPN on Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI)? (Choose two.)

choices.B: When setting up Site-to-Site VPN, customers can expect bandwidth above 2 Gbps.
choices.A: When setting up Site-to-Site VPN, it creates a private connection that provides consistent network experience.
choices.C: When setting up Site-to-Site VPN, OCI provisions redundant VPN tunnels.
choices.D: When setting up Site-to-Site VPN, customers can configure it to use static or dynamic routing (BGP).

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ABD
Incorrect: A,B,D
Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) Private Network Load Balancer support Layer 4 protocols
✅ TCP
✅ UDP
and ✅ HTTP becuse run the TCP

Selected Answer: BCD
This was a question on the official Oracle Training prep and the correct answers are TCP, UPD and ICMP. Also noted in https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/NetworkLoadBalancer/overview.htm

"You should use OCI Network Load Balancer when you require a low-latency, high-throughput, layer-4 (TCP/UDP/ICMP) load balancing solution."
And:
"Currently supported protocols include:
 TCP
 UDP
 ICMP"

Selected Answer: BCD
I agree with BCD

Not HTTP, since this is for Layer 7 Load balancer.

Selected Answer: BCD
network load balancer only works with layer 4 services.

B. UDP
C. ICMP
D. TCP

Selected Answer: ACD
HTTP, ICMP, TCP

questions.question_text: Which THREE protocols are supported by the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) private Network Load Balancers?

choices.D: Object Versioning is enabled at the namespace level.
choices.B: Object lifecycle rules can be used to either archive or delete objects.
choices.A: Immutable option for data stored in Object Storage can be set via retention rules.
choices.C: Object Storage resources can be shared across tenancies.

discussion.content:
d
About Object Versioning
Object versioning is enabled at the bucket level. Versioning directs Object Storage to automatically create an object version each time a new object is uploaded, an existing object is overwritten, or when an object is deleted. You can enable object versioning at bucket creation time or later.
From: https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Object/Tasks/usingversioning.htm
